column11: 15 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) isolated and sequenced. 11 DEGs exhibited significant sequence similarity with known function of genes or ESTs of kiwifruit. KiwiDEG1 encodes partial open reading frame (ORF) for pectin methylesterase, which plays an important role in pollen development as a cell-wall modifying enzyme. It was abundantly expressed in male floral buds suggesting its functional role in pollen development. KiwiDEG9 - full-length ORF for adenosine diphosphate (ADP)-ribosylation factor, which is a small guanosine-5'-triphosphate (GTP)-binding protein and plays an essential role in vesicle trafficking. Its expression is higher in male floral buds.

column10: Cytogenetic analysis in mitosis and meiosis
column11: Largest known Y chromosome with a probable pseudo-autosomal region, mostly heterochromatic in nature. Repeats are enriched on the Y chromosome. A 144-bp centromeric satellite repeat (CgCent) is absent in Y but present in all other autosomal chromosomes and in the X chromosome. However, evidence shows that a certain satellite is accumulated in the Y chromosome. Ty1/copia and Ty3/gypsy superfamilies are accumulated in large Y chromosome. Genes involved in plant hormone signaling pathways, such as ACS, Asr1, CsIAA2, CS-AUX1, and TLP, and their crosstalk might play a critical role in the sex determination. Ethylene response-related genes were upregulated in female buds compared to male buds. AgNO3 treatment suppressed ethylene responses in Ag-Hermaphrodite flowers by downregulation of ethylene-responsive transcription factors leading to stamen development.

column10: Cytogenetic analysis in mitosis and meiosis
column11: The expression of the floral organ identity gene CgPI is higher in male flowers (in male plants) than female flowers (in female plants) but contradicted by high expression in female flowers and reduced expression in stamens of male flowers of the gynomonoecious plant.

column10: Cytogenetic analysis in mitosis and meiosis
column11: The transcription factors such as zinc fingers, homeodomain leucine zippers and MYBs were identified as major determinants of male specific expression. column11: Satellite repeats HRTR1and HRTR8 are localized on X chromosome where HRTR8 is particularly accumulated on X chromosome. Satellite family HRTR12 is specific to Y. Sex chromosome-accumulated HRTR2 is common for both X and Y. Transposable elements like Ty3-gysy (CRM, Chromovirus, Athila) and Ty1-copia (TAR) are localized at the subtelomere region of the sex chromosome. All transposable elements represented together 24% of male and 23% of female genome. Ty1/Copia retrotransposons formed 12%, Ty3/Gypsy retrotransposons 11% and DNA transposons 1.5% of male genome.

column10: Construction and screening of male and female PAC genomic libraries
column11: On the 10 megabase (Mb) Y chromosome, 64 genes are identified, 14 of which are detected only in the male genome. These 14 genes are expressed in reproductive organs but not in vegetative thalli, suggesting their participation in male reproductive functions.

column10: Construction and screening of male and female PAC genomic libraries
column11: In the haploid dioecious liverwort, Marchantia polymorpha, the X chromosome, but not the Y, carries a cluster of ribosomal RNA genes (rDNAs). Sequences of 5S, 17S, 5.8S and 26S rDNAs are highly conserved (>99% identity) between the X chromosomal and autosomal rDNA repeat units, but the intergenic spacer sequences differ considerably. 615-bp DNA fragment in the intergenic spacer, X615, which has accumulated predominantly in the rDNA cluster of the X chromosome. These observations suggest that the rDNA repeat unit on the X chromosome evolved independently of that on autosomes, incorporating sex chromosome-specific sequences.

column10: Construction and screening of male and female PAC genomic libraries
column11: Several chromosome-specific sequence elements of approximately 70 to 400 nt are combined into larger arrangements, which in turn are assembled into extensive Y chromosome-specific stretches. These repeat sequences contribute 2-3 Mb to the Y chromosome. Novel Y chromosome-specific gene family was found embedded among these repeat sequences. This gene family encodes a putative protein with a RING finger motif and is expressed specifically in male sexual organs.

column10: Testing of the male specificity in sequences isolated using RNAseq and genome capture; sequencing of corresponding BACs from Y-chromosome; isolation of candidate sex determining genes
column11: Dioeciousness is controlled by three genes. Maleness depends on two complementary genes A and one of the B genes. Male strength (sensitivity to feminizing hormones) depends on the number of dominant B genes. Dominant A, or dominant B alone induces femaleness. Exogenous auxins induce staminate flowers on female nodes; cytokinins induce pistillate flowers on male plants. Endogenous auxin and cytokinins were measured (HPLC/GC/MS) in isogenic lines constructed for the allelic combinations of sex genes. Role of phytohormones in sex determination

column10: Testing of the male specificity in sequences isolated using RNAseq and genome capture; sequencing of corresponding BACs from Y-chromosome; isolation of candidate sex determining genes
column11: In the study populations of Durand and Durand, dioeciousness was controlled by three genes. Maleness depended mainly on the presence of dominant allele in locus A and but homozygous recessive status in two complemetary loci (B1and B2) was able to provoke femaleness. Male strength (sensitivity to feminizing hormones) depended on the number of dominant alleles in B genes. Exogenous auxins induce staminate flowers on female nodes; cytokinins induce pistillate flowers on male plants. Endogenous auxin and cytokinins were measured (HPLC/GC/MS) in isogenic lines constructed for the allelic combinations of sex genes. Role of phytohormones in sex determination was described. Current interpretation of the results by Duran and Durand 1991 can be that A locus represents the XX/XY system while two B loci were autosomal modifiers of sex expression.

column10: Testing of the male specificity in sequences isolated using RNAseq and genome capture; sequencing of corresponding BACs from Y-chromosome; isolation of candidate sex determining genes

column11: Sex determination region with suppressed recombination is located at peritelomeric region of chromosome XIX. It spans over two million bp and comprises about 65 genes. MADS box genes or homeotic. AGAMOUS orthologues gene, PTAG1 and PTAG2, three transcription factor genes, four genes related with flower development. Leucine-rich repeat (NBS–LRR) class of disease resistance genes and small microRNA are coincidently found in this sex determining region. PTD, a MADS box transcription factors belong to the family of DEFICIENS (DEF), sustain in stamen primordia but absent in carpel primordia.

column11: Two female-specific scaffolds that likely represent W-chromosome-specific sequence. We show that genes located in the SD region display a mild excess of male-biased expression in sex-specific tissue.

column10: Genetic mapping; genome wide association analysis; DNAseq
column11: SDR (sex determining region) on Chr 15 of S. purpurea (10.7–15.3 Mb) characterised, with high repeat abundance. A portion of the SDR in S. purpurea is homologous to the SDR in S. suchowensis. Tandemly duplicated kinesin-like genes in the SDR. The SDR contains 20 genes that have > 70% female-specific sequence (read coverage in the female, but not the male), and many of these genes also show sex-biased expression in developing stem tissue in S. purpurea.

column10: Genetic mapping; DNAseq
column11: Based on the established genetic maps, it was found that the gender of willow was determined by a single locus on linkage group LG_03, and the female was the heterogametic gender. Aligned with mapped SSR markers, linkage group LG_03 was found to be associated with chromosome XV in willow.

column10: Genetic mapping; DNAseq
column11: Single-locus sex determination associated with the chromosome XV. Severe recombination suppression around the gender locus.

column10: Genetic mapping; DNAseq
column11: In shrub willow, the gender locus is located on chromosome XIX and 33 genes of this chromosome are differentially expressed in male and female.

column10: Fine genetic mapping (SSR markers), sequencing of the male sex linked region via corresponging BAC detection and sequencing
column11: Mapping based on the interspecific cross Vitis vinifera ssp vinifera (hermaphroditic; cv. V3125 (‘Schiava Grossa’ × ‘Riesling’) × hybrid (Vitis riparia x Vitis cinerea)cv. ‘Börner’ (male). Sex determining region is located on chromosome 2 and about 154.8kb long containing genes Sp/sp (control pollen development) and So/so (control carpel development). Trehalose phosphatase, exostosin and WRKY transcription factor in male alleles. Several genes related with flower sex formation are located in the region one, one is adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APTs are known to also metabolize the plant hormone cytokinin). High resolution genetic map of the 143kb sex region on chromosome 2, female-sex marker in the APT sequence.

column11: VviFSEX - detected in petals, stamens and carpel primordia of all flower types, function unclear; female plants display a single allele for this gene, while male and hermaphrodites display two. VviAPRT3 - specific expressin in the carpel primordial of male plants suggests a possible role in the abortion of pistil structures. Marker for male plants.
